so we are now part of the HPD family so today we'll be speaking about kubernetes
and on the first part I'll review a little bit talk about stateful versus stateless applications we'll talk about
how AI and ml and deep learning are complex stateful applications and how
that has some challenges on kubernetes well then don't dig into what what cube director actually is a deep dive of the
technology technology itself a demonstration in some takeaways at the end so to begin with I'm young I know
this audience knows a lot about kubernetes but just kind of do a level set what is kubernetes it's an open
source platform for container orchestration what this means is it's a
collection of building blocks and services that allow containers to be
placed on individual hosts following a set of rules we say host we mean either
a virtual machine or a bare metal a physical host some are a virtual
machine in the public cloud top use cases for kubernetes up to this point
has been the deployment of stateless applications these are also known as
micro services it's a still in the evolving platform for stateful
applications that we'll be talking about that today we say stateless application
what we mean is each application service instance is identical so each container
running an instance of a stateless service is identical to any other
instance running that same service they don't have a persistence or a configuration that is unique any
information that they need to store and access is stored remotely and when we
say remotely we mean that the persistent storage has a life span different than that of the container if the container
were to exit and restart it could connect to the same persistent storage
the remote persistent storage without loss of context typically these sorts of
applications are referred to as cattle because each instance is like every other instance of that application this
is in contrast to stateful applications in a stateful application there is some
intrinsic difference to each instance of the application that's instantiated
within the container it may be as simple as a an IP address or may be more
complex and this critical information is stored locally locally means it's part
of the storage that's associated with the container when a container starts
the reason this is the case is that these applications that are considered stateful are not written in a cloud
native manner cloud native architecture where the service as the running code is
separate from the storage itself in the case of stateful applications they are
combined such applications are completely referred to as pets since each instance
is different and the loss of one such instance is a loss now we look at
stateful applications such as AI machine learning deep learning these are some of the most stateful applications we have
in the enterprise today what about all these applications have in common they
require large amounts of data and that's okay that data is typically remote it's in a de Lake external from the
containers themselves but these are complex distributed processing solutions
they are not written into cloud native architecture they are typically deployed
as collections of services running on a bare metal host or in a virtual machine
and those services have inter dependencies they are not a cloud native
architecture there's no micro services and there is an application state so
these are some of the most complex stateful applications in existence than they require special treatment
to step back for a moment when we say we're running a Hadoop or an AI or a
machine learning cluster like spark or tensor flow in containers what we're
talking about is deploying it the same way it's deployed on bare metal this is not re-architecting or rewriting the AI
or ml application what I'm showing here are four boxes which are the Primo
typical deployment strategies for Hadoop there's a resource manager as a
collection of node managers they run different services with containers what
we're talking about is putting each of those nodes into a container or potentially a pod with with kubernetes
and this entire set of containers what's referred to as a cluster so we're going
forward with the remainder of this presentation this is what we're talking about what we're saying we're deploying a cluster of containers running one of
these machine learning artificial intelligence or deep learning applications
with kubernetes we have a number of tools and building blocks to work from these are called objects pods are a
collection of containers that are deployed on an individual host we have a
concept of a stateful set stateful set refers to a set of features associated
with the kubernetes container that are necessary for running a stateful application they order the service is in
the pod that are brought up they preserve some state of the container itself that should be done with the use
of persistent volumes and each application that's deployed are we have
via a stateful set it's done via an operator and operators the collection of actions they can be performed on a per
application basis typically operators are constructed from the use of a custom
resource definition you'll also hear the term CRD kubernetes operators are a
basic API is way of packaging deploying and managing an application now that open source community has created an
operator framework it makes it easier to develop an application specific operator
and finally there's another tool on top of that called the operator SDK these are layers of abstraction which make it
easier to develop an application specific operator but still we require a
different operator for each application to be deployed on kubernetes and with
the plethora of AI and ml application is in the marketplace today this would be quite a few operators this is very
challenging for the enterprise to do so what do we need to do there's got to be
an easier way and this is what blue data has done we've used our knowledge we're helping the community with an easier
tool bluh KS you might hear that term this is a an umbrella Apache project started by
a blue data but now open to the open-source community focused solely on
bringing enterprise support for complex stateful applications to kubernetes
there'll be a series of open source projects in this case and the first thing would roll out is cube director

at this point I'd like to turn it over to Joel for a deep dive into Cupid director

motivation of this project now why would we want to create it why would someone want to use it and maybe you know as an
open source project why would someone want to contribute to it because there
are a lot of ways to deploy things on kubernetes there's a lot of solutions for getting applications to run on
kubernetes tom mentioned app specific operators there's also sort of client-side template management
solutions like helm and cube flow and if you're looking for a solution to deploy a particular thing maybe in a production
environment you're probably just going to do a a bullet point comparison of features you know does this solution do
but I wanted to do right now but from our perspective as developers and looking for you know open source
contributors and the direction of the project in the future we're also interested in asking what does the
design enable us to do as we go forward what things does our architecture of our solution make easy to do or hard to do
and there's not going to be a best solution for all you know possible purposes but we do want to find sort of
a sweet spot between two extremes of deploying applications on kubernetes you know at the one end there's a very low
level the use of the kubernetes api is and kind of making a bespoke solution
for every application when you figure out that you need to deploy that application and on the other end and this is where for example app specific
operators come in some other person who's an expert in the application and in kubernetes has put together a
solution for you kind of as a black box and it handles this application very well but if you want to tweak it or if
you want to manage other applications then it's not the best solution
so if we're going to aim for a spot between these two extremes you know we we don't want to just use the low level
make our end-users use the low level kubernetes api eyes directly so we need to build some abstractions on top of
those to guide these abstractions you know to pick what features and what data
model and what operations we support we need a focus you know we don't want to go all the way towards just supporting a
specific application but we do want to focus on this domain of big data AI machine learning data hungry these
stateful applications that Tom described and so if we look at you know what these
apps have in common from the point of view of what sort of behaviors we want to support on what sort of workflows are
interesting there's there's a lot of things that can guide our design and so that's what we're shooting forth cube
director and that's what I'm going to try to demonstrate as we go forward here so coop director itself is what's called
a custom controller this is a process that watches the kubernetes api for
resources to appear so someone else uses the cuba Nettie's api to submit a
resource to create or change or delete a resource in kubernetes persistence store
and then the controller notices that that has happened and does something and
in our case we're actually watching among other things for custom resources
to appear so we're not just interested in observing the the pods and the services and things like that that are
the sort of native kubernetes objects we've also provided some schemas to kubernetes to define some custom objects
that our coop director is specific and we'll talk a lot more about those in just a minute and these are essentially
the requests that end-users provide to kubernetes that are requesting cube
director to do something on their behalf and so when cube director sees this request it's going to again start using
the kubernetes api to create stateful sets cradle these other objects that Tom mentioned to sort of try to bring the
world into accordance with users requests now everything I've mentioned so far in this slide
this is pretty much what an app specific operator does so the way cube director
diverges from that is that the logic for determining how to respond to these
requests there's no app specific semantics coded into cube director itself cube director works with
data-driven descriptions of application types how you deploy these applications
how you manage them after they're deployed and then it uses those descriptions which can be provided by
the end user they don't have to be created by the cube director team or anybody outside the users organization
those descriptions completely Drive cube director through a state machine of deploying then managing these
applications so one obvious benefit to that is that it is some there's a
somewhat natural and easier process for bringing new applications into the fold of being deployable and manageable on
kubernetes especially if you have an existing application definition and you just maybe want to roll to a new version
of that application I use some different packages set it up in a slightly different way it's quite easy to make
that modification in these metadata files that describe the deployment but if you want to just bring a completely
new say open source application and that maybe hasn't had an operator written for it yet you can do that as well you can
create a new set of metadata and a container image for that application and give it to cube director and cube
director will know how to manage it there's also a slightly more subtle benefit from this which is that there's
other objects and features that cube director currently and especially in the future will support which are cross
cluster and cross application features things like how do you access data sources how do you authenticate users
inside your applications maybe integrating with your Enterprise ad server how do you hook clusters together
into processing pipelines and where make clusters where up other objects you defined once these features are
implemented in cube director then by virtue of providing the metadata for a new application type to cube director it
participates in those features automatically and different applications even from different developers can participate in these features together
without any knowledge of each other
so concretely speaking cube director is just a process that runs likely on the
same kubernetes platform that it's managing typically when you deploy a controller you're just going to have
some sort of deployment yamo or JSON file that describes hey you
know here's the container image to use you know maybe pull an image from docker hub or from your own internal image
repository and just to play this on kubernetes it starts up starts listening
to the kubernetes api and it's basically ready to go at that point then an end
user who wants to actually deploy a virtual cluster comes along and provides
this custom resource that I mentioned earlier this specification of the users intentions they provide a document to
the kubernetes api that says i'd like a spark cluster for example and here's a description of the resources it needs to
use and kubernetes takes that document and just stores it into its persistent
store and Etsy D so even though kubernetes has been told about the
schema for these resources it doesn't treat them as having any implied actions
it's just a document that kubernetes is managing so the you use a standard kubernetes api client to create this
resource cube director then notices that the resource has been created and that
it represents a request to create say maybe a Hadoop cluster or spark cluster and then it enters what we call the
reconciliation loop the reconciliation loop is is basically just working its
way through a state machine where it instantiates some objects in kubernetes
it takes some actions on the kubernetes api maybe it creates a stateful set maybe it creates a service and then it
goes away and then it comes back in a little while to check to see has this been completed if so it'll go to the
next part of the state machine so maybe it has to set up a pod wait until the containers are ready in that pod then
configure the application inside the pod so there's a set of steps that has to work through and meanwhile it's updating
this resource that are provided to say what the status of this process is and then once cube
director is finished working its way through the reconciliation loop the cluster is up and ready to go by using
this custom controller approach and also by taking a data-driven approach to implementing support for different
applications one of the good things about the coop director design is that it supports it doesn't require but it
supports the separation of concerns among different user types so if you have people in your organization that
have different knowledge sets maybe different privileges to do different things by virtue of the fact that
everything we do runs through the kubernetes API uses custom resources and is controllable by all the
authentication and authorization methods that kubernetes provides so for example you can say these users in this
namespace have privilege to create or modify these custom resources and these
users in this other namespace had these different privileges you can have this separation of concerns you can have
application experts who are entirely responsible for figuring out how to create the container image and the
metadata for the application but they don't have to have the privilege to install this application in kubernetes
they don't have to understand how kubernetes operators work they don't have to write go code they just have to
know how to write to this metadata format and make a container image then they can supply that to an administrator
either like an IT kind of administrator or maybe a project manager who can take
this metadata and import it into coop director and determine which users have privileged to make instances of this
application so essentially they're setting up a policy or a template for different sets of users and then the end
users can come on and again they don't have to understand how operators work they don't have to know the details of
the application or even which container image it's using they just know that here's a kind of application that's available to me I can submit a request
to kubernetes to instantiate that application that application and you know maybe there's various knobs and
controls available to the end-user like selecting the amounts of resources it's going to consume or selecting which
services it's going to run but whoever designs the application for an
appointment at this particular site can dial that complexity up and down they can decide how much complexity is
actually put onto the end user and from our perspective as Cube director we just
want this this custom resource from the end-user this request to instantiate an application to come to the kubernetes
api and then we'll tackle it we don't really care where it comes from this is probably a very rich area of development
for putting a nice user interface on top of this part of the workflow so thinking
about that that design that architecture for cube director let's call back a minute to the motivation slide you know
why would we want to have a solution architect alight cube director as opposed to some of these other things
that are available to us currently and again these other things are are very
good solutions for many use cases but coop director we're trying to make it strong for some particular use cases in this domain of applications so one thing
as I mentioned is that we support these distinctions between user roles you don't have to have a power user who
knows a lot about kubernetes and the application or someone who has privileges to do very high level
privilege things in kubernetes as well as deploy the clusters for the data scientists you can separate out these
roles and if you're using a more client-side templatized approach this is
harder to do it's not impossible but there's a lot more work to make it happen correctly because we're sort of
sitting behind the kubernetes api because we wait for documents to come through the kubernetes api before we
react to them we get the benefit of all the authentication and authorization methods that kubernetes provides and we
don't have to worry about having maybe two different sources of authority about users that might you know have to be
kept in sync with each other if you're using a solution like helm two with tiller that sits out in front of the API
where you ought indicate to that other solution first and then it sort of acts like a super user to kubernetes then you
don't have that benefit now there may be there may be reasons you want to do that approach but in many cases it's it's
more natural and more easy to keep secure if you just have this one authority of user
also because we have this process that runs that is long-lived sitting in
kubernetes watching these deployments after they're created we're not just intervening at deployment time after to
the cluster comes up we can watch it to respond to further user requests to scale it up and down we can respond to
auto scale policies to scale the cluster according to load we can auto remediate when there's errors you know when a when
a stateful node goes down there may be applications specific things that have to be done to bring it back up again all
these things require having a long-lived manager process there to watch it because these are semantics above and
beyond what kubernetes can understand or can be can be made to deal with and so
again if you're using just a a purely client-side sort of template driven approach you don't have this long-lived
manager process to take care of these things now all those things on the
previous slide all those benefits also apply to application specific operators there's a couple of other ways in which
Cube director is different from application specific operators and we've really either explicitly or implicitly
hit this point a lot up until now and that's because we are data driven by
metadata by documents that describe application types it's easier to import
new applications to be supported by this solution and you can have common features that apply across multiple
application types now if you are a single application shop or if you you
know have small number of applications that already have well-developed operators for them this may not matter to you but otherwise it might okay so
the rest of the talk we're going to be actually looking at queue director in action and talking about some details of
the way it does the things it does just to make sure that we have everybody on the same page I'm going to cover a few
bits of concepts and terminology here
this orange cloud in the middle of the of the picture we may get some other

communities resources as well as the custom resources that we've defined when someone asks a cube director to create a
virtual cluster by submitting this custom resource that asks to instantiate an application type cube director is
going to start creating objects in kubernetes and one of the important things too that you'll see when we when
we get into actual cube director activities is the concept of rolls these
squares inside the deployed virtual cluster there those are each a container acting as a virtual host like Tom
mentioned our approach to to deploying these stateful applications kind of a model that we're able to fit on a large
group of applications is to treat each container as an entire virtual host it has a file system it has a network
identity it has services running in it on the standard service ports multiple services inside each container and
within this virtual cluster among these virtual hosts we use the role concept to
distinguish different cluster members different virtual hosts that have different personalities so for a
particular role in the cluster that determines which container images used to deploy the container it determines
how many how much CPU and memory and GPU and other resources are used by the container it determines which services
are running inside this container so that's kind of our leverage point for dealing with the fact that different members inside the cluster may have
different personalities and in this particular case we've deployed a cluster that has role with one member and maybe
that's some sort of controller or manager host inside the cluster and then we have another role with three members
running different services than the previous role maybe these are some sort
of scale out worker task processing sort of role it's a common common set up in this sort of cluster
so all of these containers and they come up they're pulling a container image from some repository that's accessible to kubernetes and they may also be
pulling in some what we call configuration artifacts there's a set of
things that is convenient to pull into the container at launch time rather than
they can get into the container image either because you want to share these among being used by different container
images or just because in the in the course of development or your usual processes you revise these things and
it's kind of tedious to have to bake it back into the container image each time so when the container comes up the
application metadata may tell us that we need to pull in these extra configuration artifacts these can be
scripts that respond to lifecycle events that cube directory triggers these can
be things like application configuration file templates that the scripts use to help set up the application it could be
software licenses it could be host certificates there could be you know anything you want to put in this it's just a tar file that we inject into the
application at launch time so finally
